. The main island (which gives the municipality its name) is a large coastal island with rural landscape typical for southern Finland. It is surrounded by inner archipelago and outer archipelagos of minor islands, similar to that in the rest of the Archipeago Sea.

value: , a traditional rural village (or a couple of them) with a medieval church and some museums. The new centre by the main roads hosts large grocery stores and other service.

Bengtskär, a skerry in the outer archipelago, with the tallest lighthouse in the Nordic countries.

Kimitoön as a municipality was created 2009 by joining the municipalities of Kimito, Västanjärd and Dragsfjärd, all partly on the main island. Earlier many of the island groups and some other villages were independent municipalities. What is now Kimitoön was called Öståboland, forming the eastern part of the Åboland region (the western part, Väståboland, is now called Pargas).
speaking majority, like the rest of
. Most people also speak decent Finnish, and people know English as in the rest of Finland.
There are three roads to Kimitoön: from the north via
from national road 1 (E18) or regional road 110, both between

over the Strömma canal (said to be the only place in Finland where tides can be observed) and from north-east along small roads via the Kokkila–Angelniemi ferry. The main village, Kimito, is some 60 km from Turku, 155 km from Helsinki via

.

There are buses from Turku to Kimito and Dalsbruk about once an hour in daytime, with a few connections e.g. to Kasnäs and Västanfjärd. Buses from Helsinki more sparsely, possibly with a transfer.

With yacht you probably arrive via
in the east or via the waters of
in the west. The outer archipelago south of Kimitoön is difficult to navigate and lacks official channels.

There are good roads on the main island, suitable also for bikes, but bus transport is sparse. There are ferry connections to the main remote islands. Except Kimito, most places of interest are reachable by boat with some walking.

The main island is 60 km long from north-east – Angelniemi of Salo not counted – to Kasnäs in south-west and 40 km wide from Mjösund in north-west to Lammala in south-east.

value: Blue muzzle, information centre of the Archipelago National Park.
